Improve our alignment to physical pixel boundaries.

build_id: Previously we aligned elements to integral logical pixel boundaries
on the ratio between logical and physical pixels to be integral. This is no
longer the case in the wild world of zillions of screen sizes and densities.
Our new approach is to leave logical position/size alone until validation
which point we ensure that our boundaries (top
integral physical pixels and then translate those back to an updated logical
position and size which are used when laying out deeper children.

Previously LayoutData had three jobs:
1. Track any resolved style or ephemeral data which is needed to layout a
widget. This stuff is only needed for layout
preferred size
pull_req: then throw it away. That way we're not keeping

build_id: around a bunch of crap for every single widget during normal operation.
2. Use the resolved data to compute widget's preferred size
LayoutData.computeSize().
3. Use the resolved data to lay the widget out
But this sucked when you just wanted to make a minor tweak to computeSize() or
layout() based on some non-ephemeral state. You had to create a special
subclass of LayoutData just to hold the code that really should have been in
the Element subclass instead.
There was also some fiddly shenanigans with BaseLayoutData and LayoutData for
probably stupid reasons that have long since been forgotten.
Now there's just one LayoutData class
methods: computeSize() and layout()
commit: and two Element methods (of the same name)

build_id: which delegate to the LayoutData methods by default.
In cases where a simple tweak is needed (Box
ImageButton)
commit: no custom LayoutData class is needed at all. The Element

build_id: subclasses just override the methods that would have delegated to LayoutData
and do the right thing right there. Simple!
In one case (Scroller)
commit: ScrollerLayoutData is used to track some ephemeral

build_id: data
commit: but we still handle the computeSize() and layout() in Scroller's methods

build_id: rather than ScrollerLayoutData's methods (mainly because we're specializing
Composite/Container
commit: which now do their layout in Element.layout).

build_id: In a few other cases (TextWigdet
pull_req: we still do things the "old" way

build_id: where TextWidgetLayoutData and SliderLayoutData implement computeSize() and
layout() directly
commit: because they resolve a shit ton of layout data and it's nice

build_id: to be able to access that stuff directly via the this pointer.
I was tempted to convert everything to "Scroller"-style where all LayoutData
subclasses were just structs that held extra data and all custom logic went
into the Element subclass
commit: but I needed to preserve the old LayoutData methods

build_id: and behavior for all the custom code out in the wild that has created its own
LayoutData subclass. So since that has to live on
commit: I might as well use it in

build_id: the few cases where it's tidier.
Previously even if all elements in a row were non-visible
rowgap was still being inserted.

message: Element can now track bindings to reactive values.

build_id: This allows the element to establish a connection when it is added to a UI
hierarchy and dispose of it when it is removed. Doing so relieves the caller of
managing the lifetime of the connection themselves
leaky.
Often the lifetime of a reactive value and a UI element that displays it do not
coincide
commit: and the reactive value long outlives the element

build_id: leaks if special care is not taken to ensure that connections are closed when
the element goes away. This bind mechanism makes that easy to do
concise
commit: and cheaper than creating a Closeable.Set and binding it to the

build_id: element's hierarchy signal (which was the only general purpose way to do this
before this change).
Sometimes you want to set these things fluently

message: Only bind to our value when we're added to the UI.

build_id: This allows us to display values which outlive our UI without worrying that
garbage views will keep listening and responding to value changes.

message: A bit of DWIM wrt the first frame of a transition.

build_id: This is a bit like ScreenStack
commit: but different enough to not really benefit from

build_id: sharing code. A ScreenSpace provides an infinite 2D grid metaphor
screens slide in from a direction
commit: and the user then goes "back" by sliding the

build_id: current screen back in the direction from whence it came.
Care has been taken to allow a ScreenSpace to interact comfortably with screens
that scroll (via Flicker). So you can
pull_req: scroll a new screen UP into

build_id: view
commit: then then allow the user to continue scrolling up to see the whole

build_id: scrolled screen. But if they scroll DOWN while looking at the top of the
screen
commit: this initiates an untransition gesture which takes them back to the

build_id: previous screen.
Naturally when you transition screens orthogonally to the main scroll direction
(slide new screen in LEFT and then scroll up and down)
well.
This is not yet totally complete. There are some non-space transitions to be
implemented (IN/OUT which will zoom and cross fade to simulate going INto our
OUT of the plane
pull_req: which will work like ScreenStack's flip). These

build_id: non-space transitions will not afford user initiated untransition gestures
in those cases the app will have to provide back buttons
nice to have the option to include non-spatial transitions where they make
sense.
I'm also going to support a horizontally scrolled
style UI screen where the screen supports an arbitrary number of UI Roots each
of which is laid out vertically
commit: and the user can use sliding gestures to go

build_id: left and right between them. Naturally
commit: this will be set up so that if you want

untransition to the previous screen if that's how these screens came in
can transition vertically into a left/right navigable screen
go UP to get out of it (which is nice because they can use UP regardless of

commit: the logic was scattered all over the damned place and the copies

build_id: weren't consistent. AnimGroup was checking canceled
duplication is now gone and the logic is necessarily consistent because it only

I changed the canceled check to cause things to blow up. Either you cancel()
your animations or you complete() them. You don't mix and match. There's no way
we can do anything reasonable in such circumstances
The makeComplete() (nee complete()) method is now documented as being
idempotent so that we can now simply go through the whole animation chain and
mark every animation is complete whether or not it has been previously
processed.
If a layer is in an animation chain multiple times
moveTo(layerA
and the first animation has already completed before complete() is called
the first animation will move layerA to pointA during the completion process
but the second animation will move layerA to pointB immediately afterwards
aside from a miniscule amount of extra effort (possibly offset by vastly
simpler completion logic) there will be no visible funny business. Everything
will end up where it should be were the animation chain allowed to complete
normally.
It is possible that a totally separate animation chain was queued up to
manipulate a layer after the first one completed
commit: but then that first one went

build_id: on to do other things and was complete()d later
of the second spawned animation chain. But arguably you should be completing
all animation chains in that case and completing them in the order that they
were spawned
commit: so you should still be OK. Though you really shouldn't be doing

build_id: such crazy shit in the first place.
I also removed Repeat _isCompleted tracking because it didn't make any sense.
At first I thought animation chains were intended to be reused
possible. complete() also cancel()s the animations
cancel()ed
commit: it can never be reused. Moreover

build_id: next() will never be called on it. So there are no circumstances in which
Repeat would need to return something special from next() after it had been
complete()d.

hate a comment saying one the line above using a variable saying

build_id: This gives a very significant performance improvement both in not having to do the drawing and not having to allocate the temporary memory in any situation where other layout changes are needing to happen frequently.
Entity is now a reusable container for an int and some bit flags. This
eliminates the "extend Entity and sneak some stuff in your class" approach
you can just wrap an Entity in your sneaky class if you really want do to that.
I considered eliminating Entity entirely and just passing around an int
the need to box the int to dispatch entityAdded/Changed/etc. signals made me
rethink things. The goal with pooled entities is zero GC during normal
operation
commit: and boxing would thus be a no-no. I could keep the Integer instances

build_id: around
commit: but at that point I might as well create my own "box" (aka Entity)

build_id: which can also have the "interested systems" and "attached components" bit
masks
commit: along with a few other flags.

build_id: This also eliminates the limit on number of systems and components. Yay BitVec.

message: Fixing issue where contents were displayed offset within the frame.

build_id: The entired contents of the window were occassionally being shifted out of the frame. Controls were responding as if the widgets were in their normal position. This was fairly reproducable by running more than one instace of TripleDemoJava at once.
Calling pack() before the JFrame is shown consistently fixes this. According to Oracle
commit: pack() is meant to be called before setVisible(true) anyway. This has only been reported on OSX. This was fairly reproducable by running more than one instace of TripleDemoJava at once.

build_id: As the wordy comment indicates
commit: this is a simple way to "fix" the jerkiness

build_id: caused by a screen loading up a bunch of images in wasAdded(). The loading is
not long enough to merit making a big deal out of it with a loading screen or
something
pull_req: but 100ms causes a big jerk when you're normally

build_id: expecting animation frames to arrive every 15ms.
A "proper" solution is to load images asynchronously and then only start
rendering once they're loaded (though then you still have the delay caused by
uploading textures to the GPU on the first frame)
shit out of client code with a bunch of image callbacks and blah blah blah
Java provides no good programming language constructs to keep that from
overwhelming your otherwise simple UI initialization code with boilerplate and
callback spaghetti.
